title: 109_hr6419
content: The "Nuclear Terrorism Prevention Act of 2006" is the short title of this Act. It includes definitions for various terms used in the legislation. The Act defines key terms such as "Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material," "design-basis threat," "formula quantities of strategic special nuclear material," and "Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty." The Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons was signed in 1968 and came into force in 1970. It defines a nuclear weapon as any device using atomic energy for weapon purposes. SEC. 3. FINDINGS. Congress finds that the threat of terrorists acquiring and using a nuclear weapon is urgent and poses a significant risk to national and global security. Efforts to secure nuclear stockpiles and combat nuclear terrorism have made progress, but further actions are necessary. The White House and United Nations have both emphasized the grave consequences of a nuclear terror attack, highlighting the need for continued vigilance and international cooperation. United Nations Security Council Resolution 1540 (2004) emphasizes the need to prevent terrorist acts involving nuclear, chemical, or biological weapons. The Director General of the International Atomic Energy Agency warns of the urgent threat of a terrorist attack using a nuclear weapon. Sense of Congress on the prevention of nuclear terrorism. The sense of Congress is that the threat of nuclear terror is the most horrific the United States faces. A comprehensive approach is needed to reduce this danger, including efforts to identify and eliminate terrorist groups seeking nuclear weapons, secure nuclear weapons worldwide, and prevent terrorist efforts to manufacture or transport nuclear explosives. The prevention of a nuclear terrorist attack should be a top priority for the President. The President should prioritize preventing a nuclear terrorist attack on the United States by accelerating programs to combat nuclear smuggling and secure strategic nuclear material. The International Atomic Energy Agency should be appropriately funded to coordinate international efforts in protecting nuclear materials. Legislation by Senators Lugar, Domenici, and Nunn has led to groundbreaking programs to prevent nuclear weapons from falling into the hands of terrorists. The National Security Act of 1947 is amended to include a new section for a senior advisor to the president for the prevention of nuclear terrorism. The National Security Act of 1947 is amended to include a Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism, appointed by the President with Senate approval. The Senior Advisor's duties include advising the President on nuclear terrorism matters, formulating US policies for prevention, developing plans with measurable targets, addressing program gaps, and overseeing program implementation strategies. The Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism is responsible for advising the President on nuclear terrorism matters, formulating US prevention policies, developing plans with measurable targets, addressing program gaps, overseeing program implementation strategies, and coordinating US efforts to implement policies. The Senior Advisor may appoint and terminate necessary personnel to perform duties. Additionally, the Senior Advisor is now a member of the National Security Council. The Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism is now included as a member of the National Security Council. Additionally, a new paragraph is inserted after paragraph (6) regarding the Senior Advisor's role. The Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism is now a member of the National Security Council. An annual report is required. The President must submit an annual report to Congress on the security of strategic special nuclear material, including a survey of facilities worldwide and a list of high-priority sites. The Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism is involved in this program. The annual report to Congress includes a list of high-priority sites for the removal or security of nuclear weapons and related materials, along with a plan for securing vulnerable facilities worldwide. The report also details efforts by governments to secure such materials. The annual report to Congress includes a list of high-priority sites for securing nuclear weapons and related materials, along with efforts to establish and implement security standards and policies. The report may be submitted in classified form but must include a detailed unclassified summary. SEC. 7 outlines the minimum security standard for nuclear weapons and strategic special nuclear materials. The United States policy is to ensure the security and accountability of all nuclear weapons and special nuclear materials. In line with international standards, the President will work towards a global agreement on nuclear security that effectively protects against threats from terrorists and criminals, considering equipment and human limitations, and is verifiable. In furtherance of the policy to ensure nuclear security, the President will collaborate with other countries and the International Atomic Energy Agency to upgrade security measures in countries with nuclear weapons or special nuclear materials. Financial and technical assistance will be provided to accelerate security upgrades. The President will collaborate with other countries to ensure effective nuclear security rules and regulations worldwide, including implementing a regulatory design-basis threat model to defeat threats from terrorists and criminals. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal year 2008 totaling $50,000,000 to increase international participation in converting nuclear facilities from highly enriched uranium to low enriched uranium and to remove highly enriched uranium from such facilities.
